Title:
Phylogenetic placement of Ivodea and biogeographic affinities
of Malagasy Rutaceae
Abstract:
The genus Ivodea Capuron is endemic to Madagascar and the
Comoros and consists of 30 species. This study is the first to include
the genus in a molecular phylogenetic analysis. We sequenced the plastid
trnL-trnF and the nuclear ITS regions for three Ivodea species and
revealed that the genus is monophyletic and most closely related to the
African and Malagasy Vepris Comm. ex A.Juss., refuting earlier
suggestions of a close relationship between Ivodea and the Asian,
Malesian, Australasian and Pacific genera Euodia J.R.Forst. &
G.Forst. and Melicope J.R.Forst. & G.Forst. Ivodea and Vepris
provide another example of closely related pairs of Rutaceous groups
that have drupaceous and capsular/follicular fruits, respectively, and
thus further confirming that fruit types are not suited to delimit
subfamilies in Rutaceae, as has often been done in the past. Ivodea was
the last of the seven Malagasy genera to be included in the Rutaceae
phylogeny, making it possible to conduct an assessment of biogeographic
affinities of the genera that occur on the island. Our assessments based
on sister group relationships suggest that the eight lineages
(representing seven genera) of Malagasy Rutaceae either have African
(three lineages) or Asian affinities (two lineages), although taxon
sampling is insufficient to interpret the directionality of dispersal
events in the remaining three lineages.
